courseTitle: Effects on Microbial Growth: Water Activity and Osmotic Pressure

pageData.text: Cells live in the presence of aqueous solutions, in which water is the solvent and various solutes (salts, sugars, amino acids, etc.) are dissolved. The cytoplasm within a cell is an aqueous solution, and its water and solute content must be maintained within a narrow range to sustain life. Thus, solute concentration in a cellular microbe’s external environment exerts a powerful influence on its ability to metabolize and reproduce. Some microorganisms will only grow in the presence of a high solute concentration, but most thrive in an environment with more water and less solute. In this investigation, the student will observe the effect of varying salt concentrations on bacterial growth.

pageData.text:
Climate change is not only causing sea levels to rise, but it also changes the salinity of the ocean. As more glaciers and sea ice melts, more fresh water enters the oceans and lowers the salinity. In some regions, drought is causing increased levels of evaporation, and salinity is increasing. The salinity of seawater is important and even small changes in it can have huge impacts on the water cycle and ocean circulation1. In addition, the salinity of seawater can have devastating impacts on plants, animals, and microbes. Marine plankton are the base of the food web in the ocean. They are also responsible for producing about 50-80% of the oxygen on Earth, of which approximately 10% becomes the air we breathe. When there are changes in temperature, CO2, and salinity plankton populations shift. There is potential that changes in the salinity of the ocean can have devastating effects on the diversity of marine plankton, which impact the food web and the atmosphere2.1NASA. (2023). Salinity. pageData.text: Increasing the amount of salt in food products—such as fish, meat, and even some vegetables—is an ancient method of preservation that predates refrigeration. The increase in salt concentration removes water from cells by a process called <button class='glossary-text'>osmosis</button>. Osmosis is the net, or overall, movement of water down its concentration gradient, from an area of higher water molecule concentration (and therefore lower solute particle concentration) to an area of lower water concentration (and therefore higher solute concentration) across a semipermeable membrane that allows water, but not solute, to move freely.

Osmotic pressure is a measure of the different concentrations of water and solute in two adjacent areas separated by a semipermeable membrane. In Figure 1, the water molecules are represented by small, blue spheres and the solute particles by larger, red spheres. Due to osmosis, water molecules in the solute-free area (on the right side of the membrane) move through the semipermeable membrane toward the area containing solute particles. The resulting osmotic pressure is clearly seen as the level of the solution on the left side of the membrane rises above that on the right. Water molecules can cross the membrane freely, so there is always some random movement of individual molecules in both directions (as indicated by the bidirectional arrow in Figure 1). But the net water movement is toward the area where solute is abundant. The greater the difference in the solute concentration across the membrane, the greater the osmotic pressure will be.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Diagram of a container of water divided in half vertically by a semipermeable membrane. On the right, the liquid level is low and consists only of water molecules. On the left, the liquid level is high and includes solute particles as well as water molecules.

pageData.text: Because most solutes in cells are not able to cross membranes, the only way to equalize the concentration of solutes in two adjacent areas is by increasing the volume of water in the area with the higher concentration of solute. The necessary water is supplied from an adjacent area with a lower concentration of solute.

When two solutions have the same amount of solute, the solutions are said to be . However, when one solution has a greater concentration of solute, the solution is said to be . Conversely, when one solution has a lower concentration of solute, it is said to be . It is helpful to visualize what happens to the water content of a cell in solutions of different tonicities (solute concentrations) as shown in Figure 2. A human red blood cell is essentially a sac filled with cytoplasm, and it lacks a cell wall, so changes in cell shape and size in response to salt in the environment can be quite dramatic and nearly instantaneous. In an isotonic solution, the cell maintains its usual size and shape. In a hypotonic environment, water enters the cells and causes it to become enlarged. In a hypertonic environment, the cell shrivels as water is drawn out.

Most bacterial cells do not exhibit such a marked visual response to a change in salt concentration due to their cell walls, which give them a less variable size and shape. However, they are still affected. The best way to assess the effect of salt concentration in the environment of such microbes is to observe their growth over time.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Drawing of three human red blood cells in solutions of three different salt concentrations. From left to right: a cell with normal shape and size in isotonic solution; a swollen cell in hypotonic solution; and a shriveled cell in hypertonic solution.

pageData.text: Osmotic pressure also can be described in terms of or aw. Pure, distilled water, which is water that does not contain any solute particles, is the standard. At a certain temperature, only a specific amount of water can be in the vapor state, which is apparent in nature. For example, no water will accumulate on a car on a hot summer night but on a cold fall night, water vapor will condense out of the air onto the surface of the car. The amount of water that can be in the vapor state in the air is called the . At higher temperatures, there is a higher dew point, meaning more water can be present in the vapor state in the air. At lower temperatures, the dew point is lower and less water vapor is present in the air.

Water activity is defined as the partial vapor pressure of water in a substance divided by the partial vapor pressure of pure, distilled water at the same temperature. This can be written as:<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>a<sub className=bodySubscript>w</sub> = P / P<sub className=bodySubscript>0</sub>

where water activity is a<sub class='bodySubscript'>w</sub>, P is the vapor pressure of the solution, and the vapor pressure of distilled water is P<sub class='bodySubscript'>0</sub>. (It is assumed that the temperature of the distilled water and the solution are identical.) Distilled water is assigned an a<sub class='bodySubscript'>w</sub> value of 1.00; thus, the presence of solute in water will lower the a<sub class='bodySubscript'>w</sub>. For example, the aw of soy sauce, a salty condiment, is about 0.810.

Water will always migrate from an area of high a<sub class='bodySubscript'>w</sub> to an area of low a<sub class='bodySubscript'>w</sub>. Therefore, an environment or substance with a low a<sub class='bodySubscript'>w</sub> can dry out a substance with a lower a<sub class='bodySubscript'>w</sub>. The mummies of Egypt are good examples of preservation using this technique. The air in Egypt is extremely dry and has low a<sub class='bodySubscript'>w</sub>, much lower than that of human tissue, so the dry air naturally <button class='glossary-text'>desiccates</button> (dries out) and preserves the body. Bodies to be mummified were buried in hot, very dry sand to hasten the drying process and improve preservation. The process of mummification was further refined by the application of natron, a naturally occurring mixture of sodium salts known for its extreme desiccation capabilities.

Microorganisms such as bacteria and fungi need water to transport materials through the cell and for many of their metabolic processes. If there is too little water in the microbe, its metabolic functions will slow and may even be halted completely. Some microorganisms are able to reduce the effects of drying out by producing proteins that increase the solute content inside the cell, lowering the a<sub class='bodySubscript'>w</sub>. This reduces the concentration gradient between the inside of the cell and its surrounding environment and enables the organism to survive.

Most microbes live in slightly saline environments. The media commonly used for routine culturing of bacteria contain 0.5% salt. Some microbes can survive in elevated salt conditions and are said to be ; such organisms do not, however, require high salinity for growth. Microorganisms that require extremely salty environments to survive and grow are called . Bodies of water like the Dead Sea and the Great Salt Lake can contain up to five times more salt than seawater (which is 3.5% salt). Such environments can support an abundance of halophilic microbes. Figure 3 shows the salt pans in Sicily. Salt pans are naturally occurring or artificial shallow pools filled with saltwater. As the water evaporates, the salt concentration increases until it can be easily collected. The bright pink color of the water in Figure 3 is due to the presence of halophilic microorganisms.

Various solutes besides salts can affect a<sub class='bodySubscript'>w</sub>, including sugars. Jams and jellies typically have a<sub class='bodySubscript'>w</sub> of 0.80–0.84, and the aw of honey is approximately 0.48–0.64. The reaction of a microorganism to a low a<sub class='bodySubscript'>w</sub> due to sugar concentration depends on the ability of the organism to metabolize sugar.

In this investigation, you will examine the effect of <button class='glossary-text'>water activity</button> on microbial growth by introducing two different bacterial species into nutrient broth containing different concentrations of salt (sodium chloride).

typeBefore.text: Note: Use correct aseptic technique as you are working through this investigation. You may wish to review the Aseptic Technique and Use of Media investigation to refresh your memory. In particular, each time you remove the cap from a tube, the cap should be held, not placed on the work surface. The open mouth of each glass culture tube should be flamed as soon as the cap is removed and immediately before the cap is replaced.

Culture Recommendations: You will need very fresh broth cultures of E. coli and S. epidermidis for this investigation to be successful.
  • If you have a broth culture that is no more than two weeks old, you may skip Preparation Steps 6–13.
  • If you need to reactivate lyophilized cultures, follow the directions that came with the cultures using proper aseptic technique. You may wish to first review the video:

Both organisms will grow at room temperature; however, they will grow faster around 37° C (99° F). Once growth is apparent in the tryptic soy broth, you may skip Preparation Steps 6–13.
  • If you have a broth culture that is more than two weeks old, carry out all of the Preparation steps before proceeding to the activity.
Follow your instructor’s directions on whether to keep or discard your E. coli and S. epidermidisss cultures at the end of this investigation.

pages.title: Activity 1
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Inoculation of Media with Varying Salt Concentrations (2 steps)

pageData.text: Using the grease pencil or permanent marker, label one room temperature nutrient broth tube of each salt concentration for each of the different cultures with the name of the bacterium (e.g., take the 0% NaCl tubes and label one “E. coli” and the other “S. epidermidis,” then repeat for the 5%, 10%, and 15% NaCl tubes).

pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol
pageData.text: Using a fresh inoculating loop each time, aseptically inoculate the four tubes labeled “E. coli” with a loop of your E. coli broth culture. Repeat for the tubes labeled “S. epidermidis,” using your S. epidermidis broth culture. Place each loop into the disposal jar after use, and allow it to sit for at least 30 minutes before discarding according to the Disposal and Cleanup directions.
Let the cultures incubate with caps slightly loose for 24 hours.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Photograph the culture tubes together for each bacterium.Record the amount of growth for each treatment in Data Table 1.
After another 24 hours of incubation (48 hours total), photograph each set of culture tubes again. Record the amount of growth for each treatment in Data Table 1.

To dispose of used inoculating loops, let them soak in the disposal jar with isopropyl alcohol for at least 30 minutes. Then, while wearing PPE, pour the alcohol down the drain with the faucet running. Allow the faucet to run for at least 30 seconds to dilute the alcohol. Wrap the loops in an opaque plastic bag, and put them in the garbage.
Keep your original broth cultures unless otherwise directed by your instructor.

text: Describe the effect of increasing salt concentration on bacterial growth observed in this investigation. How did each species respond to salt concentration?
Is either of the two bacterial species you tested a halophile? Explain your answer.

Some strains of Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus are able to cause food poisoning if the food in which they are growing is consumed. All strains of E. coli grow in similar environmental circumstances. Likewise, S. aureus grows in similar conditions as its close relative S. epidermidis. Which species would be more likely to cause food poisoning by growing in deli meats such as ham: E. coli or S. aureus? Explain your answer.

A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. Before beginning the investigation, you will disinfect your work surface, prepare your disposal jar and prepare your cultures. To begin, label each type of nutrient broth tube with a bacteria species. Then, you will inoculate each tube with the designated bacteria. When you have inoculated all 8 tubes, you will incubate your cultures. After 24 and 48 hours of incubation, you will record the amount of growth in each tube.

data.title: Dew point
data.content: The amount of water that can be in the vapor state in the air

data.title: Halophile
data.content: A microorganism that requires extremely salty environments to survive and grow

data.title: Halotolerant
data.content: Describes a microbe that can survive in elevated salt conditions

data.title: Hypertonic
data.content: Describes the solution with the higher solute concentration when comparing two solutions with different solute concentrations

data.title: Hypotonic
data.content: Describes the solution with the lower solute concentration when comparing two solutions with different solute concentrations

data.title: Isotonic
data.content: Describes two solutions that have the same solute concentration

data.title: Osmosis
data.content: A special type of diffusion in which water molecules diffuse across a selectively permeable membrane

data.title: Water activity (a<sub class='bodySubscript'>w</sub>)
data.content: A measure of osmotic pressure; pure distilled water is the standard at 1.00
